archetype_name: Family Weekend Showstopper: Indian Feast Night
name: Chicken Dum Biryani Feast with Mirch Ka Salan and Cucumber-Mint Raita
description: Layered chicken dum biryani finished in the oven, served with a classic peanut–sesame mirch ka salan and cooling cucumber-mint raita. A weekend showstopper with medium heat and big aroma.
prep_steps: Rinse 3 cups basmati rice in cold water until it runs mostly clear; soak 20 minutes, then drain.
Slice 4 large onions thinly; keep 1 large onion separate for the salan.
Finely chop 1 cup mint and 1 cup coriander; reserve half for garnish.

In a bowl, mix 1 cup yoghurt, 3 tbsp biryani mix, 1 tsp garam masala, 1 tsp salt, juice of 1 lemon, and half the chopped mint/coriander; add 1.2 kg chicken thighs and coat well. Marinate 30–60 minutes (longer is better).
Warm 1/4 cup milk and steep a big pinch saffron; set aside.
Measure whole spices for rice: 2 bay leaves, 6 cardamom, 6 cloves, 1 cinnamon stick.
For salan: measure 1/3 cup peanuts, 2 tbsp sesame seeds, 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1 cup coconut milk, 2 tbsp tamarind chutney.
Halve 10–12 chilies (keep seeds for heat) and slice 1 cucumber for raita.
cook_steps: Fry onions for biryani: Heat 3 tbsp oil and 2 tbsp ghee in a wide pan over medium-high. Fry 3 of the sliced large onions with 1/2 tsp salt, stirring, until deep golden and crisp at edges (15–20 minutes). Remove half for layering; leave the rest in the pan.

Parboil rice: Bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil with 1 tbsp salt, the bay leaves, cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon. Add soaked rice; cook 5–6 minutes until 70% done. Drain; spread briefly to steam off.

Start chicken base: In the onion pan, add the marinated chicken and 2 crushed garlic cloves. Sear 3–4 minutes per side until lightly colored. Turn heat to low; cook 5 minutes to start releasing juices. Turn off heat.

Layer biryani (dum): Transfer chicken and its juices to a heavy oven-safe pot. Scatter half the reserved fried onions, half the remaining mint/coriander, and 4–5 halved chilies over chicken. Spread the parboiled rice on top. Drizzle saffron milk and 1 tbsp ghee over rice. Top with remaining fried onions and herbs.
Seal and bake: Cover pot tightly with a lid (use foil under lid if loose). Bake at 180°C/350°F for 35–40 minutes. Rest 10 minutes before opening.
Make mirch ka salan paste: In a dry pan, toast 1/3 cup peanuts and 2 tbsp sesame seeds over medium heat until fragrant (3–4 minutes). Add 1/2 cup water and blend to a smooth paste.

Cook salan: In a saucepan, heat 2 tbsp oil. Add 1 tsp mustard seeds and 1 tsp cumin seeds; let them crackle. Add the reserved 1 large sliced onion; cook until golden. Stir in the peanut–sesame paste, 1 cup coconut milk, 2 tbsp tamarind chutney, 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, 1/2 tsp salt, and 1 cup water. Add 6–8 halved chilies. Simmer gently 12–15 minutes until thick, adjusting water as needed. Salt to taste.
Mix raita: Whisk 1 cup yoghurt with a pinch of salt and 1/2 tsp cumin. Fold in sliced cucumber and 2 tbsp chopped mint.
Finish biryani: Gently fluff the top rice layer, then fold down into the chicken in two or three scoops to keep layers intact. Taste and adjust salt.
Serve: Plate biryani with extra herbs on top. Ladle mirch ka salan alongside and add a spoon of raita.
